subsection.title: Trigonometric Functions of Angles in Radians
subsection.p: Measuring angles in radians has other applications besides calculating arclength, and we will need to evaluate trigonometric functions of angles in radians. The sine, cosine, or tangent of a particular angle is the same whether the angle is measured in radians or in degrees.

For example, \dfrac{\pi}{3} radians is the same as 60\degree, because \dfrac{\pi}{3} \cdot \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi} = 60\degree, so \sin \dfrac{\pi}{3} = \sin 60\degree = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} However, we don't have to convert radians to degrees in order to evaluate trig ratios; your calculator can give you the trigonometric function values for angles expressed in radians. First, change the calculator setting from Degree mode to Radian mode. Then enter \boxed{\text{SIN}}~(\pi / 3) and the calculator will return 0.8660254038. You can check that this number is a decimal approximation for \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.

Your calculator will give you the values \begin{aligned}[t] \cos (3.5) \amp = -0.9364566873\\ \sin (3.5) \amp = -0.3507832277\\ \end{aligned} Rounding to four places, we have \cos (3.5) = -0.9365 and \sin (3.5) = -0.3508. Note that 3.5 radians is a third-quadrant angle, so the signs of the trig values make sense.

note.p: Recall the formula for arclength when the angle is measured in radians: s = r \theta. If we solve for \theta, we see that \theta = \dfrac{s}{r}, a ratio of two lengths. The units of length cancel out, so that radian measure has no units; it is a "dimensionless" quantity.
We shall see that this property makes radians especially useful in applications. From now on we shall omit the tag "radians," and you may assume that any angle given without units is in radians.

subsection.title: The Special Values
subsection.p: Many applications of trigonometric functions, including most of the periodic functions we encountered in Chapter 5, use radians for input values, rather than degrees. For this reason, it is important to know the trig values for the special angles, which you learned in degrees in Chapter 2, when the angles are given in radians.
You should memorize these function values, and be able to use them to find trig values for the special angles in all four quadrants.

subsection.title: Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers
subsection.p: In Section 6.1 we derived the arclength formula, s = r\theta, where \theta is measured in radians, and observed that, on a unit circle where r = 1, the measure of a positive angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans. This is an important observation, because it allows us to define the sine and cosine as functions of real numbers, instead of as functions of angles.

sidebyside.p: Consider the unit circle shown at right, and the angle \theta determined by the arc of length t. The radian measure of \theta is the same as the length t of the arc. (For example, in this figure \theta = t = 2.)

assemblage.title: Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers
assemblage.p: We define the trigonometric functions of the number t by \cos t = \cos \theta ~~~~\text{and} ~~~~ \sin t = \sin \theta where t is the length of the arc subtended by an angle \theta, measured in radians, on a unit circle.

subsection.p: We can think of the definition this way: to find the sine or cosine of a real number t, we draw an arc of length t on a unit circle, and then find the sine or cosine of the angle \theta determined by the arc.

note.p: In practice, there is no difference between finding the sine or cosine of the number 2 and the sine or cosine of an angle of 2 radians: in each case we set the calculator in Radian mode and evaluate \boxed{\text{COS}}~ 2 = -0.4161~~~~\text{and} ~~~~ \boxed{\text{SIN}}~ 2 = 0.9093

statement.p: The sunset time in Stockholm, Sweden, on the nth day of the year can be modeled by T = 3.11 \sin (0.017n - 1.38) + 6.03 where T is given in hours after noon. Find the sunset time on January 1 (day n = 1) and on July 1 (day n = 182).

solution.p: Evaluate the function for n = \alert{1} to find T = 3.11 \sin (0.017(\alert{1}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 2.99 On January 1, sunset in Stockholm occurs about 2.99 hours after noon, or at 2:59 pm.

Evaluate the function at n = \alert{182} to find T = 3.11 \sin (0.017(\alert{182}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 9.11 On July 1, sunset occurs about 9.11 hours after noon, or at 9:07 pm. (Actually, 10:07 pm, because of daylight savings time.)

subsection.title: Coordinates on a Unit Circle
subsection.p: There is another useful connection between the unit circle and the trigonometric functions. Consider an arc of length t in standard position on a unit circle, and the angle \theta spanned by the arc. Because r = 1 on a unit circle, \cos \theta = \dfrac{x}{r} = \dfrac{x}{1}~~~~\text{and}~~~~ \sin \theta = \dfrac{y}{r} = \dfrac{y}{1} But because \cos t = \cos \theta and \sin t = \sin \theta, we have \cos t = x ~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~ \sin t = y We have established the following result for the sine and cosine of a real number t.

sidebyside.p: The coordinates of the point P determined by an arc of length t in standard position on a unit circle are (x, y) = (\cos t, \sin t)

subsection.p: We sometimes call the trigonometric functions of arclength, \sin t and \cos t, the circular functions, because they are defined by the coordinates of points on a unit circle.

statement.p: Find the coordinates of the terminal point, P, of an arc of length t starting at (1,0) on a unit circle.

sidebyside.p: On a unit circle, the coordinates of P are (\cos \dfrac{\pi}{2}, \sin \dfrac{\pi}{2}), so x = \cos \dfrac{\pi}{2} = 0~~~\text{and}~~~ y = \sin \dfrac{\pi}{2} = 1 The coordinates of P are (0,1), as shown at right.

li.p: (We could also observe that an arc of length \dfrac{\pi}{2} is one quarter of a unit circle, so the point P sits at the twelve o'clock position on the circle.)

sidebyside.p: The coordinates of P are (\cos \dfrac{5\pi}{6}, \sin \dfrac{5\pi}{6}), so \begin{aligned}[t] x \amp= \cos \dfrac{5\pi}{6} = \dfrac{-\sqrt{3}}{2}~~~\\ y \amp= \sin \dfrac{5\pi}{6} = \dfrac{1}{2}\\ \end{aligned} Thus, the coordinates of P are (\dfrac{-\sqrt{3}}{2},\dfrac{1}{2}), as shown at right.

subsection.title: The Tangent Function
subsection.p: We can also define the tangent function for real numbers. Let P(x,y) be the terminal point of an arc of length t in standard position on a unit circle. Then

sidebyside.p: \tan t = \dfrac{y}{x} Of course, this definition agrees with our earlier definition of the tangent function for angles, because the point P lies on the terminal side of the angle \theta = t radians.

subsection.p: For example, we saw earlier that, rounded to four decimal places, \cos 2 = -0.4161~~~~\text{and} ~~~~ \sin 2 = 0.9093 so the coordinates of point P on the unit circle in the figure above are (-0.4161, 0.9093). Therefore, \tan 2 = \dfrac{0.9093}{-0.4161} = -2.1853 You can set your calculator in radian mode to verify that, to three decimal places, \boxed{\text{TAN}} ~2 = -2.185 We now have the following definitions for the circular functions of real numbers.
